BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Main danger: fresh snowdrifts at high altitudes
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Fresh snowdrifts are trigger-prone at high altitudes. Size and frequency of danger zones increase with ascending altitude. Danger zones are covered, they occur in ridgeline terrain, behind discontinuities and in wind-loaded gullies and bowls, increasingly occur also distant from ridges. Small-to-medium sized avalanches can be triggered by one person. Backcountry sports require much experience in assessing avalanche dangers on-site and prudent route selection; mind the risks of falling. Small loose-snow avalanches are possible in steep rocky terrain due to solar radiation. Despite lower temperatures, glide-snow avalanches are still a threat on steep grass-covered and rocky slopes in all aspects, avoid zones below glide cracks.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Strong to stormy winds have transported the loose snow, generating trigger-prone snowdrift accumlations. Older drifts are bonding better with the surface, but with increasing altitude are still prone to triggering, esp on high-altitude shady slopes. The old snowpack below them is generally well consolidated and stable. The warm ground and wet lower layers are reinforcing the gliding movement of the entire snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.wxSynopsisComment: Nocturnal hours: Fresh snowfall (10-30 cm) above 1000 m widespread in evening and nighttime hours. Strong winds will transport this. Tuesday daytime: Snow showers will taper off, clouds will disperse, visibility improve. Starting at midday, a warm front will move in, create diffuse light conditions. At 2000 m: -6 to -3 degrees. Strong to stormy W/NW winds.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Starting on Wednesday, variable conditions with mild temperatures and storm-strength winds. Avalanche danger levels are not expected to change significantly.

Danger zones occur in ridgeline terrain, behind discontinuities and in wind-loaded gullies and bowls. Small-to-medium sized avalanches can be triggered by one person. Danger zones are being blanketed over and are difficult to recognize. Despite lower temperatures, glide-snow avalanches are still a threat on steep grass-covered and rocky slopes in all aspects, avoid zones below glide cracks.

The old snowpack below them is generally well consolidated and stable. The warm ground and wet lower layers are reinforcing the gliding movement of the entire snowpack, esp. where there is rain impact.
